trial_identification.studytitle: Postural assessment of children between 7 and 10 years of age
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Postural assessment of children between 7 and 10 years of age for asymmetry

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal musculoskeletal and cartilage development and function
Normal musculoskeletal and cartilage development and function

interventions.interventions: qualitative assessment of posture of head, shoulder (frontal and sagittal planes), scapula, cervical lordosis, thoracic kyphosis, lumbar lordosis, spine lateral deviation, trunk rotation, pelvis, hip (frontal plane), knee (frontal and sagittal planes), ankle, hallux, forefoot. Duration of the observation was 20 minutes

primaryOutcome.outcome: postural deviations. The tool used was a plumbline and the simetrografo

secondaryOutcome.outcome: flexibility. The tool used was a tape measure

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: children with neuromuscular and/or traumatic pathologies

ethicsAndSummary.summary: During the infancy, the posture undergoes many adjustments related to growth stages due to changes of the body proportions. The formation of the body schema, in childhood, occurs through the motor experiences and allows the tonic-postural structuration, so the postural imbalance obtained in this period can last for the entire adolescence and adult life. The purpose of this study was to identify which postural alterations occur most often in students between 7 and 10 years of age, to identify preventive measures, and to provide information to parents and teachers about the problem of bad posture.
